xccdf:Benchmark.xccdf:title: CIS Google Chrome Benchmark

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This document provides prescriptive guidance for establishing a secure configuration posture for Google Chrome Browser. This guide was tested against Google Chrome v96. To obtain the latest version of this guide, please visit http://benchmarks.cisecurity.org . If you have questions, comments, or have identified ways to improve this guide, please write us at feedback@cisecurity.org .

IMPORTANT NOTE: This Benchmark assumes the installation of the Goggle Chrome and Google Update ADMX/ADML templates into the Active Directory policy store for the domain(s) of interest. These can be obtained at the following web locations:
Some helpful guidance on using this Benchmark.

This Benchmark has high-level sections based on various security related concerns (Enforced Defaults, Privacy, etc.). Within each of these major sections the recommendations are ordered alphabetically, and are grouped in the relevant sub-section where the setting is located in the Google Chrome GPO as shown in the Microsoft Group Policy Management Editor when the GPO is sorted alphabetically by setting (Clicking the Setting column in the Microsoft Group Policy Management Editor right pane view).
Many of the settings specified in this Benchmark are also the default settings for the browser. These are specified for the following reasons:

xhtml:ol.xhtml:li: The default (Unset) setting may have the same effect as what is prescribed, but they allow the user to change these settings at any time. Actually configuring the browser setting to the prescribed value will prevent the user from changing it.

Many organizations want the ability to scan systems for Benchmark compliance and configuration drift using CIS (CIS-CAT) or CIS certified third party tools ( CIS Vendor Partners ). Having these settings specified in the Benchmark allows for this.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This benchmark is designed to use Windows Group Policy on a domain joined system to set the appropriate Windows registry values that pertain to Google Chrome. In the end, these settings change the internal "policy" configuration of Google Chrome. These "Policy" settings can be viewed in Google Chrome directly by typing chrome://policy/ directly into the Google Chrome address box.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Items in this profile intend to:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: be the starting baseline for most organizations;
be practical and prudent;
provide a clear security benefit; and
not inhibit the utility of the technology beyond acceptable means.

xccdf:Profile.xccdf:title: Level 2 (L2) - High Security/Sensitive Data Environment (limited functionality)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This profile extends the "Level 1 (L1)" profile. Items in this profile exhibit one or more of the following characteristics:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: are intended for environments or use cases where security is more critical than manageability and usability;
may negatively inhibit the utility or performance of the technology; and
limit the ability of remote management/access.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Note: Implementation of Level 2 requires that both Level 1 and Level 2 settings are applied.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section contains recommendations that are configured by default when you install Google Chrome. Enforcing these settings at an enterprise level can prevent these settings from changing to a less secure option.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Cross-origin HTTP Authentication prompts' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether third-party sub-content can open a HTTP Basic Auth dialog and is typically disabled.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: This setting is typically disabled to help combat phishing attempts.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\HTTP authentication\Cross-origin HTTP Authentication prompts
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Configure the list of domains on which Safe Browsing will not trigger warnings' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The setting determines the functionality of Safe Browsing.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0): Safe Browsing protection applies to all resources
Enabled (1), with a list of 1 or more sites: Means Safe Browsing will trust the domains you designate. It won't check them for dangerous resources such as phishing, malware, or unwanted software.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)
NOTE: Safe Browsing's download protection service won't check downloads hosted on these domains, and its password protection service won't check for password reuse.

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Google Safe Browsing will help protect users from a variety of malicious and fraudulent sites, or download dangerous files.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Safe Browsing settings\Configure the list of domains on which Safe Browsing will not trigger warnings
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

NOTE: The only real impact is possible user annoyance if the are going to a legitimate site that is falsely considered fraudulent (a rare occurrence). This an be handled by adding the site to the allowlist and/of notifying Google of the false finding.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Safe Browsing Protection Level' is set to 'Enabled: Standard Protection' or higher

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Control whether Google Chrome's Safe Browsing feature is enabled and the mode it operates in. If you set this setting as mandatory, users cannot change or override the Safe Browsing setting in Google Chrome.
If this setting is left not set, Safe Browsing will operate in Standard Protection mode but users can change this setting.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: No Protection (0): Safe Browsing is never active
Standard Protection (1): Safe Browsing is active in the standard mode
Enhanced Protection (2): Safe Browsing is active in the enhanced mode

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Standard Protection (1) or higher

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Google Safe Browsing will help protect users from a variety of malicious and fraudulent sites, or download dangerous files.
For more details please refer to the items in the References section below..

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: Standard Protection :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Safe Browser settings\Safe Browsing Protection Level
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior (Standard Protection).

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow Google Cast to connect to Cast devices on all IP addresses' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether Google Cast is able to connect to all IP Addresses or only private IP Addresses as defined in RFC1918 (IPv4) and RFC4193 (IPv6). Note that if the EnabledMediaRouter setting is set to Disabled there is no positive or negative effect for this setting.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Ensure Only Approved Ports, Protocols and Services Are Running

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing Google Cast to connect to public IP addresses could allow media and other potentially sensitive data to be exposed to the public. Disabling this setting will ensure that Google Cast is only able to connect to private (ie: internal) IP addresses.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Allow Google Cast to connect to Cast devices on all IP addresses
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow queries to a Google time service' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether Google Chrome can send queries to a Google time service for accurate timestamps. This check helps in validation of certificates.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled (1)

controls:safeguard.title: Standardize Time Synchronization
Utilize Three Synchronized Time Sources

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Google Chrome uses a network time service to randomly track times from a trusted external service. This allows Google Chrome the ability for verification of a certificate's validity and is important for certificate validation.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Enabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Allow queries to a Google time service
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow the audio sandbox to run' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether audio processes in Google Chrome run in a sandbox.
NOTE: Security software setups within your environment might interfere with the sandbox.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled (1)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Having audio processes run in a sandbox ensures that if a website misuses audio processes that data may not be manipulated or exfiltrated from the system.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Enabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Allow the audio sandbox to run
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Ask where to save each file before downloading' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers to download files automatically to the default download directory without prompting.
If this setting is enabled, users are always asked where to save each file before downloading.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled (1)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Users shall be prevented from the drive-by-downloads threat.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Ask where to save each file before downloading
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Continue running background apps when Google Chrome is closed' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome allows for processes started while the browser is open to remain running once the browser has been closed. It also allows for background apps and the current browsing session to remain active after the browser has been closed.
With this setting Disabled, the browser will close its processes and will stop running background apps.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Ensure Only Approved Ports, Protocols and Services Are Running

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If this setting is enabled, vulnerable or malicious plugins, apps and processes can continue running even after Chrome has closed.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Continue running background apps when Google Chrome is closed
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Control SafeSites adult content filtering' is set to 'Enabled: Filter top level sites (but not embedded iframes) for adult content' specified

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can use the Google Safe Search API to classify URLs as pornographic or not.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled with a value of Filter top level sites (but not embedded iframes) for adult content (1)

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing search results to present sites that may have malicious content should be prohibited to help ensure users do not accidentally visit sites that are more prone to malicious content including spyware, adware, and viruses.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: Do not filter sites for adult content :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Control SafeSites adult content filtering.
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users search results will be filtered and content such as adult text, videos and images will not be shown.
NOTE: Using Googles Safe Search API may leak information which is typed/pasted by mistake into the omnibox, e.g. passwords, internal webservices, folder structures, etc.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Determine the availability of variations' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Configuring this setting allows specifying which variations are allowed to be applied in Google Chrome. Variations provide a means for Google to offer modifications to Google Chrome without shipping a new version of the browser by selectively enabling or disabling already existing features.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: CriticalFixesOnly (1): Allows only variations considered critical security or stability fixes to be applied to Google Chrome.

VariationsDisabled (2), prevent all variations from being applied to the browser. Please note that this mode can potentially prevent the Google Chrome developers from providing critical security fixes in a timely manner and is thus not recommended.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)
NOTE: Google strongly believes there is no added security benefit for turning this to critical fixes as leaving it on increases the stability of the browser.

controls:safeguard.title: Perform Automated Application Patch Management
Deploy Automated Software Patch Management Tools
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Google strongly recommends to leave this setting at the default (0 = Enable all variations), so fixes are gradually enabled (or if necessary, rapidly disabled) via the Chrome Variations framework.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled (same as VariationsEnabled):
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Determine the availability of variations
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Disable Certificate Transparency enforcement for a list of Legacy Certificate Authorities' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can disable the enforcing of Certificate Transparency requirements for a list of Legacy Certificate Authorities.
If this setting is disabled, certificates not properly publicly disclosed as required by Certificate Transparency are untrusted.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Legacy Certificate Authorities shall follow the Certificate Transparency policy.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Disable Certificate Transparency enforcement for a list of Legacy Certificate Authorities
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Disable Certificate Transparency enforcement for a list of subjectPublicKeyInfo hashes' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can exclude certificates by their subjectPublicKeyInfo hashes from enforcing Certificate Transparency requirements. If this setting is disabled, no certificates are excluded from Certificate Transparency requirements.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Certificate Transparency requirements shall be enforced for all certificates.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Disable Certificate Transparency enforcement for a list of subjectPublicKeyInfo hashes
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Disable Certificate Transparency enforcement for a list of URLs' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can specify URLs/hostnames for which Certificate Transparency will not be enforced. If this setting is disabled, no URLs are excluded from Certificate Transparency requirements.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Certificates that are required to be disclosed via Certificate Transparency shall be treated for all URLs as untrusted if they are not disclosed according to the Certificate Transparency policy.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Disable Certificate Transparency enforcement for a list of URLs
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Disable saving browser history' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome is configured to save the browser history.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)
NOTE: This setting will preserve browsing history that could contain a users personal browsing history. Please make sure that this setting is in compliance with organizational policies.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Browser history shall be saved as it may contain indicators of compromise.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Disable saving browser history
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'DNS interception checks enabled' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting determines whether a local switch is configured for DNS interception checks. These checks attempt to discover if the browser is behind a proxy that redirects unknown host names.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled (1)

NOTE: This detection might not be necessary in an enterprise environment where the network configuration is known. It can be disabled to avoid additional DNS and HTTP traffic on start-up and each DNS configuration change.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Disabling these checks could potentially allow DNS hijacking and poisoning.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Enabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\DNS interception checks enabled
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable component updates in Google Chrome' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome's Component Updater updates several components of Google Chrome on a regular basis (applies only to Chrome browser components).
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled (1)

NOTE: Updates to any component that does not contain executable code, does not significantly alter the behavior of the browser, or is critical for its security will not be disabled (E.g. certificate revocation lists and Safe Browsing data is updated regardless of this setting). FYI chrome://components lists all components, but not if they are are affected by this settings.
NOTE: Google provided the following list of "some of the components" controlled by this settings:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Recovery component
Pnacl
Floc
Optimization hints
SSL error assistant
CRL set
Origin trials
SW reporter
PKI metadata

controls:safeguard.title: Perform Automated Application Patch Management
Deploy Automated Software Patch Management Tools

notes:notes.xhtml:p: To check the current components versions navigate to chrome://components .

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Google Chrome Updater shall be used to keep the components bundled to Chrome up-to-date.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable component updates in Google Chrome
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable globally scoped HTTP auth cache' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether HTTP auth credentials may be automatically used in the context of another web site visited in Google Chrome.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)
NOTE: This setting is intended to give enterprises depending on the legacy behavior a chance to update their login procedures and will be removed in the future.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing HTTP auth credentials to be shared without the users consent could lead to a user sharing sensitive information without their knowledge. Enabling this setting could also lead to some types of cross-site attacks, that would allow users to be tracked across sites without the use of cookies.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable globally scoped HTTP auth cache
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable online OCSP/CRL checks' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can reactivate soft-fail, online revocation checks although they provide no effective security benefit.
If this setting is disabled, unsecure online OCSP/CRL checks are no longer performed.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: CRLSets are primarily a means by which Chrome can quickly block certificates in emergency situations. As a secondary function they can also contain some number of non-emergency revocations. These latter revocations are obtained by crawling CRLs published by CAs.

Online (i.e. OCSP and CRL) checks are not, by default, performed by Chrome. The underlying system certificate library always performs these checks no matter what Chrome does, so enabling it here is redundant.

An attacker may block OCSP traffic and cause revocation checks to pass in order to cause usage of soft-fail behavior. Furthermore, the browser may leak what website is being accessed and who accesses it to CA servers.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable online OCSP/CRL checks
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable Renderer Code Integrity' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether unknown and potentially hostile code will be allowed to load inside of Google Chrome.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled (1)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Disabling this setting could have a detrimental effect on Google Chrome's security and stability as unknown, hostile, and/or unstable code will be able to load within the browser's renderer processes.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Enabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable Renderer Code Integrity
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable security warnings for command-line flags' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting prevents Google Chrome from showing security warnings that potentially dangerous command-line flags are in use at its' launch.
The recommended state of this setting is: Enabled (0)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If Google Chrome is being launched with potentially dangerous flags this information should be exposed to the user as a warning, if not the user may be unintentionally using non-secure settings and be exposed to security flaws.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Enabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable security warnings for command-line flags
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable third party software injection blocking' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can prevent third party software from injecting executable code into Chrome's processes.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled (1)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Third party software shall not be able to inject executable code into Chrome's processes.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable third party software injection blocking
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enables managed extensions to use the Enterprise Hardware Platform API' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting allows extensions installed by enterprise policies to be allowed to use the Enterprise Hardware Platform API.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Ensure Only Approved Ports, Protocols and Services Are Running

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: It is recommended that this setting is disabled unless otherwise directed by Enterprise policies.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enables managed extensions to use the Enterprise Hardware Platform API
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Ephemeral profile' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether user profiles are switched to ephemeral mode. In ephemeral mode, profile data is saved on disk for the length of the session and then the data is deleted after the session is over. Therefore, no data is saved to the device.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing use of ephemeral profiles allows a user to use Google Chrome with no data being logged to the system. Deleting browser data will delete information that may be important for a computer investigation and investigators such as Computer Forensics Analysts may not be able to retrieve pertinent information to the investigation.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Ephemeral profile
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Import autofill form data from default browser on first run' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether users are allowed to import autofill data from other browsers into Google Chrome.

If you set this setting to Disabled users will be unable to perform an import of autofill data during Google Chrome run. This will also prevent users from importing data after Google Chrome has been setup.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing autofill data to be imported could potentially allow sensitive data such as personally identifiable information (PII) from a non-secured source into Google Chrome. Considering that storage of sensitive data should be handled with care disabling this setting is recommended.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Import autofill form data from default browser on first run
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Import of homepage from default browser on first run' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether users are able to import homepage settings from another browser into Google Chrome as well as whether homepage settings are imported on first use.
If you set this setting to Disabled users will be unable to perform an import homepage settings from other browsers into Google Chrome.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Having the homepage setting automatically imported or allowing users to import this setting from another browser into Google Chrome allows for the potential of compromised settings being imported into Google Chrome.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Import of homepage from default browser on first run
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Import search engines from default browser on first run' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether users are able to import search engine settings from another browser into Google Chrome as well as whether said setting is imported on first use.
If you set this setting to Disabled users will be unable to perform an import of their search engine settings from other browsers into Google Chrome.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Having search engine settings automatically imported or allowing users to import the settings from another browser into Google Chrome could allow for a malicious search engine to be set.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Import search engines from default browser on first run
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'List of names that will bypass the HSTS policy check' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting allows a list of names to be specified that will be exempt from HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) policy checks then potentially upgraded from http:// to https://.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing hostnames to be exempt from HSTS checks could allow for protocol downgrade attacks and cookie hijackings.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\List of names that will bypass the HSTS policy check
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Origins or hostname patterns for which restrictions on insecure origins should not apply' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can use a list of origins (URLs) or hostname patterns (such as "*.example.com") for which security restrictions on insecure origins will not apply and are prevented from being labeled as "Not Secure" in the omnibox.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Insecure contexts shall always be labeled as insecure.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Origins or hostname patterns for which restrictions on insecure origins should not apply
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Suppress lookalike domain warnings on domains' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting prevents the display of lookalike URL warnings on the sites listed. These warnings are typically shown on sites that Google Chrome believes might be trying to spoof another site the user is familiar with.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0) or set to an empty list: Warnings may appear on any site the user visits.
Enabled (1) and set to one or more domains: No lookalike warnings pages will be shown when the user visits pages on that domain.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Look-alike domains are intentionally misleading to give users the false impression that theyre interacting with trusted brands, leading to significant reputation damage, financial losses, and data compromise for established enterprises.

In addition, this technique is commonly use to host phishing sites, and often lead to account takeover attacks. Users are prompted to enter their credentials on a fake website, and scammers take control of their online accounts with little effort to engage in fraudulent activity.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Suppress lookalike domain warnings on domains
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

NOTE: The only real impact is possible user annoyance if the are going to a legitimate site that is falsely considered fraudulent (a rare occurrence). This an be handled by adding the site to the allowlist and/of notifying Google of the false finding.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Suppress the unsupported OS warning' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome will show a warning that appears when Google Chrome is running on a computer or operating system that is no longer supported.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Ensure Authorized Software is Currently Supported
Ensure Software is Supported by Vendor

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The user shall be informed if the used software is no longer supported.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Suppress the unsupported OS warning
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'URLs for which local IPs are exposed in WebRTC ICE candidates' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting specifies a list of URLs or patterns which local IP address will be exposed by WebRTC.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)
NOTE: This setting, if Enabled, weakens the protection of local IPs if needed by administrators.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Enabling this setting and allowing exposure of IP addresses can allow an attacker to gather information about the internal network that could potentially be utilized to breach and traverse a network.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\URLs for which local IPs are exposed in WebRTC ICE candidates
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section contains recommendations that help reduce the overall attack surface. Organizations should review these settings and any potential impacts to ensure they make sense within the environment since they restrict some browser functionality.
These setting are not in the normal \Google\Google Chrome\ section of the GPO.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Update policy override' is set to 'Enabled' with 'Always allow updates (recommended)' or 'Automatic silent updates' specified

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Update manages installation of available Google Chrome updates from Google. This setting allows to define whether updates are to be applied automatically. Depending on the business scenario updates shall be applied periodically or also if the user seeks for updates.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Updates disabled : Never apply updates (0)
Always allow updates : Updates are always applied when found, either by periodic update check or by a manual update check (1)
Manual updates only : Updates are only applied when the user does a manual update check (2)
Automatic silent updates only : Updates are only applied when they are found via the periodic update check (3)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Disabled (0): Google Update handles available updates as specified by "Update policy override default".
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled with a value of Always allow updates (1) or Automatic silent updates (3)
NOTE: This policy is available only on Windows instances that are joined to a Microsoft Active Directory domain.

controls:safeguard.title: Perform Automated Application Patch Management
Deploy Automated Software Patch Management Tools

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Software updates shall be applied as soon as they are available since they may include latest security patches.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: Always allow updates (recommended) or Enabled: Automatic silent updates only :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Update\Applications\Google Chrome\Update policy override
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Latest updates are automatically applied at least periodically.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Control use of insecure content exceptions' is set to 'Enabled: Do not allow any site to load mixed content'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Setting controls whether users can add exceptions to allow mixed content for specific sites.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Do not allow any site to load mixed content (2)
Allow users to add exceptions to allow mixed content (3)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled with the value of Do not allow any site to load mixed content (2)
NOTE: This policy can be overridden for specific URL patterns using the InsecureContentAllowedForUrls and InsecureContentBlockedForUrls policies.

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Subscribe to URL-Categorization service

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing mixed (secure / insecure) content from a site can lead to malicious content being loaded. Mixed content occurs if the initial request is secure over HTTPS, but HTTPS and HTTP content is subsequently loaded to display the web page. HTTPS content is secure. HTTP content is insecure.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: Do not allow any site to load mixed content :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Content Settings\Do not allow any site to load mixed content
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will not be able to mix content.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Control use of the Web Bluetooth API' is set to 'Enabled: Do not allow any site to request access to Bluetooth devices via the Web Bluetooth API'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome has an API which allows the access to nearby Bluetooth devices from the browser with users consent.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Do not allow any site to request access to Bluetooth devices via the Web Bluetooth API (2)
Allow sites to ask the user to grant access to a nearby Bluetooth device (3)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled with a value of Do not allow any site to request access to Bluetooth devices via the Web Bluetooth API (2)

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Disable Wireless Peripheral Access of Devices

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: A malicious website could exploit a vulnerable Bluetooth device.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: Do not allow any site to request access to Bluetooth devices via the Web Bluetooth API :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Content Settings\Control use of the Web Bluetooth API
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is configured, websites no longer can access nearby Bluetooth device via the API (this includes web cameras, headphones, and other Bluetooth devices) and the user will never be asked.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Control use of the WebUSB API' is set to 'Enabled: Do not allow any site to request access to USB devices via the WebUSB API'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome has an API which allows the access to connected USB devices from the browse

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Do not allow any site to request access to USB devices via the WebUSB API (2)
Allow sites to ask the user to grant access to a connected USB device (3)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled with a value of Do not allow any site to request access to USB devices via the WebUSB API (2)

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Manage USB Devices

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: WebUSB is opening the doors for sophisticated phishing attacks that could bypass hardware-based two-factor authentication devices (e.g. Yubikey devices).

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: Do not allow any site to request access to USB devices via the WebUSB API :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Content Settings\Control use of the WebUSB API
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If this setting is configured, websites can no longer access connected USB devices via the API (this includes web cameras, headphones, and other USB devices) which could also prevent some two factor authentication (2FA) USB devices from working properly.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Default notification setting' is set to 'Enabled: Do not allow any site to show desktop notifications'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers websites to display desktop notifications. These are push messages which are sent from the website operator through Google infrastructure to Chrome.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Allow sites to show desktop notifications (0)
Do not allow any site to show desktop notifications (1)
Ask every time a site wants to show desktop notifications (2)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled with a value of Do not allow any site to show desktop notifications (1)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If the website operator decides to send messages unencrypted Google's servers may process it as plain text. Furthermore, potentially compromised or faked notifications might trick users into clicking on a malicious link.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: Do not allow any site to show desktop notifications selected from the drop down:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Content Settings\Default notification setting
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is enabled and set to Do not allow any site to show desktop notifications , notifications will not be displayed for any sites and the user will not be asked.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Blocks external extensions from being installed' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Enabling this setting blocks external extensions (an extension that is not installed from the Chrome Web Store) from being installed.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled (1)

controls:safeguard.title: Restrict Unnecessary or Unauthorized Browser and Email Client Extensions
Disable Unnecessary or Unauthorized Browser or Email Client Plugins

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing users to install extensions from other locations (not the Chrome Web Store) can lead to malicious extensions being installed.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Extensions\Blocks external extensions from being installed
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
User will only be allowed to install extension for the Chrome web store.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Configure allowed app/extension types' is set to 'Enabled: extension, hosted_app, platform_app, theme'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Enabling this setting allows you to specify which app/extensions types are allowed.
Disabled (0): Results in no restrictions on the acceptable extension and app types.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled with the values of extension , hosted_app , platform_app , theme

controls:safeguard.title: Restrict Unnecessary or Unauthorized Browser and Email Client Extensions
Disable Unnecessary or Unauthorized Browser or Email Client Plugins

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: App or extension types that could be misused or are deprecated shall no longer be installed.

NOTE: Google has removed support for Chrome Apps which includes the types hosted_app and platform_app. The blog post indicates that these types will require a setting to be enabled for continued use through June 2022.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: extension, hosted_app, platform_app, theme :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Extensions\Configure allowed app/extension types
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Extensions already installed will be removed if it's type is denylisted and the extension itself is not allowlisted.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Configure extension installation blocklist' is set to 'Enabled: *'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Enabling this setting allows you to specify which extensions the users can NOT install. Extensions already installed will be removed if blocklisted.
Disabled (0): then the user can install any extension in Google Chrome.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled with a value of *

NOTE: Chrome does offer a more granular permission based configuration called Extension management settings if blocklisting all extensions is too aggressive, which allows an organization to drill down to the exact permissions that they want to lock down. The extensions management settings requires more coordination and effort to understand what the security requirements are to block site and device permissions globally as well as more IT management to deploy, the benefit would allow access to more extensions to their end-users. See link in reference section

NOTE: If Chrome Cleanup is Disabled, users my want to configure the extension blocklist instead of using the Extension Management option. Chrome Cleanup can help protect against malicious extensions when paired with the Extension Management setting.

controls:safeguard.title: Restrict Unnecessary or Unauthorized Browser and Email Client Extensions
Disable Unnecessary or Unauthorized Browser or Email Client Plugins

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: This can be used to block extensions that could potentially allow remote control of the system through the browser. If there are extensions needed for securing the browser or for enterprise use these can be enabled by configuring either the setting Configure extension installation allowlist or the setting Extension management settings .

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: * :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Extensions\Configure extension installation blocklist
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

Any installed extension will be removed unless it is specified on the extension allowlist, if an organization is using any approved password managers ensure that the extension is added to the allowlist.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Supported authentication schemes' is set to 'Enabled: ntlm, negotiate'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Specifies which HTTP authentication schemes are supported by Google Chrome.
Disabled (0): Allows all supported authentication schemes.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled with the value of ntlm, negotiate

controls:safeguard.title: Encrypt Sensitive Data in Transit
Encrypt Transmittal of Username and Authentication Credentials

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Possible values are 'basic', 'digest', 'ntlm' and 'negotiate'. Basic and Digest authentication do not provide sufficient security and can lead to submission of users password in plaintext or minimal protection (Integrated Authentication is supported for negotiate and ntlm challenges only).

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: ntlm, negotiate :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\HTTP Authentication\Supported authentication schemes
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If some legacy application(s) or website(s) required insecure authentication mechanisms they will not work correctly.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Configure native messaging blocklist' is set to 'Enabled: *'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Allows you to specify which native messaging hosts that should not be loaded.
Disabled (0): Google Chrome will load all installed native messaging hosts.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled with a value of *
NOTE: This needs to be handled carefully. If an extension is enabled, yet can't communicate with its backend code, it could behave in strange ways which results in helpdesk tickets + support load.

controls:safeguard.title: Restrict Unnecessary or Unauthorized Browser and Email Client Extensions
Disable Unnecessary or Unauthorized Browser or Email Client Plugins

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: For consistency with Plugin and Extension policies, native messaging should be blocklisted by default, requiring explicit administrative approval of applications for allowlisting. Examples of applications that use native messaging is the 1Password password manager.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: * specified.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google Chrome\Native Messaging\Configure native messaging blocklist
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
A blocklist value of '*' means all native messaging hosts are blocklisted unless they are explicitly listed in the allowlist.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable saving passwords to the password manager' is Explicitly Configured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome has a built in password manager to store passwords for users. Chrome will use local authentication to allow users to gain access to these passwords.
The recommended state for this setting is: Explicitly set to Enabled (1) or Disabled (0) based on the organization's needs.
NOTE: If you choose to Enable this setting please review Disable synchronization of data with Google and ensure this setting is configured to meet organizational requirements.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The Google Chrome password manager is Enabled by default and each organization should review and determine if they want to allow users to store passwords in the Browser. If another solution is used instead of the built in Chrome option then an organization should configure the setting to Disabled .

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, configure the following setting to meet organizational requirements:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Password manager\Enable the password manager
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Organizationally dependent.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable Google Cloud Print Proxy' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting enables Google Chrome to act as a proxy between Google Cloud Print and legacy printers connected to the machine.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets and Software
Ensure Only Approved Ports, Protocols and Services Are Running

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Disabling this option will prevent users from printing documents from unmanaged devices to an organization's printer.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Printing\Enable Google Cloud Print Proxy
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, users cannot enable the proxy, and the machine will not be allowed to share its local printers with Google Cloud Print.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section has recommendation specifically for configuring Chrome Remote Desktop.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: Ensure 'Allow remote access connections to this machine' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This is a setting for Chrome Remote desktop. If this setting is Disabled, the remote access host service cannot be started or configured to accept incoming connections.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0): Prevent remote access connections to this machine
Enabled (1): Allow remote access connections to this machine

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Manage Access Control for Remote Assets
Manage All Devices Remotely Logging into Internal Network

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Only approved remote access systems should be used.
NOTE: If Chrome Remote Desktop is approved and required for use, then this setting can be ignored.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Remote Access\Allow remote access connections to this machine
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
This setting will disable Chrome Remote Desktop. In general, Chrome Remote Desktop is not used by most businesses, so disabling it should have no impact.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow remote users to interact with elevated windows in remote assistance sessions' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can be set to run the remote assistance host in a process with uiAccess permissions. This allows remote users to interact with elevated windows on the local user's desktop.
If this setting is disabled, the remote assistance host will run in the user's context. Furthermore, remote users cannot interact with elevated windows on the desktop.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Manage Access Control for Remote Assets
Manage All Devices Remotely Logging into Internal Network

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Remote users shall not be able to escalate privileges.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Remote access\Allow remote users to interact with elevated windows in remote assistance sessions
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Configure the required domain names for remote access clients' is set to 'Enabled' with a domain defined

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome allows the configuration of a list domain(s) that are allowed to access the user's system. When enabled, remote systems can only connect if they are one of specified domains listed.
Setting this to an empty list (Disabled) allows remote systems from any domain to connect to this users system.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled (1) and at least one domain set
NOTE: The list of domains is organization specific.

controls:safeguard.title: Manage Access Control for Remote Assets
Manage All Devices Remotely Logging into Internal Network

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Remote assistance connections shall be restricted.

xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Remote access\Configure the required domain names for remote access clients
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is enabled, only systems from the specified domains can connect to the user's system.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable curtaining of remote access hosts' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Allow someone physically present at the host machine to see what a user is doing while a remote connection is in progress.
If this setting is disabled, host's physical input and output devices are enabled while a remote connection is in progress.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Manage Access Control for Remote Assets
Manage All Devices Remotely Logging into Internal Network

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If a remote session is in progress the user physically present at the host machine shall be able to see what a remote user is doing.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Remote access\Enable curtaining of remote access hosts
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
None - This is the default behavior.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable firewall traversal from remote access host' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome enables the usage of STUN servers which allows remote clients to discover and connect to a machine even if they are separated by a firewall. By disabling this feature, in conjunction with filtering outgoing UDP connections, the machine will only allow connections from machines within the local network.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Manage Access Control for Remote Assets
Manage All Devices Remotely Logging into Internal Network

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If this setting is enabled, remote clients can discover and connect to this machines even if they are separated by a firewall.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Remote access\Enable firewall traversal from remote access host
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled and outgoing UDP connections are filtered by the firewall, this machine will only allow connections from client machines within the local network.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable or disable PIN-less authentication for remote access hosts' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome allows a user to opt-out of using user-specified PIN authentication and instead pair clients and hosts during connection time.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Manage Access Control for Remote Assets
Manage All Devices Remotely Logging into Internal Network

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If this setting is enabled, users can opt to pair clients and hosts at connection time, eliminating the need to enter a PIN every time.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Remote access\Enable or disable PIN-less authentication
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, users will be required to enter PIN every time.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable the use of relay servers by the remote access host' is set to 'Disabled'.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome allows the use relay servers when clients are trying to connect to this machine and a direct connection is not available.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disable (0): The use of relay servers by the remote access host in not allowed
Enabled (1): The use of relay servers by the remote access host is allowed

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Manage Access Control for Remote Assets
Manage All Devices Remotely Logging into Internal Network

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Relay servers shall not be used to circumvent firewall restrictions.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Remote access\Enable the use of relay servers by the remote access host
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, remote clients can not use relay servers to connect to this machine.
NOTE: Setting this to Disabled doesn't turn remote access off, but only allows connections from the same network (not NAT traversal or relay).

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow download restrictions' is set to 'Enabled: Block dangerous downloads'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can block certain types of downloads, and won't let users bypass the security warnings, depending on the classification of Safe Browsing.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Block dangerous downloads (1)
Block potentially dangerous downloads (2)
Block all downloads (3)
Block malicious downloads (4)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled with a value of Block dangerous downloads (1)

NOTE: These restrictions apply to downloads triggered from webpage content, as well as the Download link... menu option. They don't apply to the download of the currently displayed page or to saving as PDF from the printing options.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Users shall be prevented from downloading certain types of files, and shall not be able to bypass security warnings.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: Block dangerous downloads :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Allow download restrictions
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If this setting is enabled, all downloads are allowed, except for those that carry Safe Browsing warnings. These are downloads that have been identified as risky or from a risky source by the Google Safe Browsing Global intelligence engine
.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Allow proceeding from the SSL warning page' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls whether a user is able to proceed to a webpage when an invalid SSL certificate warning has occurred.
The recommended state for this setting is: Disabled (0)

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Sites protected by SSL should always be recognized as valid in the web browser. Allowing a user to make the decision as to whether what appears to be an invalid certificate could open an organization up to users visiting a site that is otherwise not secure and or malicious in nature.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Disabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Allow proceeding from the SSL warning page
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users will not be able to click past the invalid certificate error to view the website.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Disable proceeding from the Safe Browsing warning page' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google provides the Safe Browsing service. It shows a warning page when users navigate to sites that are flagged as potentially malicious.
Disabled (0): Users can choose to proceed to the flagged site after the warning appears.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled (1)

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Malicious web pages are widely spread in the internet and pose the most significant threat to the user today. Users shall be prevented from navigating to potentially malicious web content.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Disable proceeding from the Safe Browsing warning page
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Enabling this setting prevents users from proceeding anyway from the warning page to the malicious site. In some cases legitimate sites could be blocked and users would be prevented from accessing.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable Chrome Cleanup on Windows' is Configured

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome provides a Cleanup-feature to detect unwanted software. This feature periodically scans the system for unwanted software and will ask the user if they wish to remove it, if any has been found.
The recommended state for this setting is: Explicitly set to Enabled (1) or Disabled (0) based on the organization's needs.

controls:safeguard.title: Centrally Manage Anti-Malware Software
Utilize Centrally Managed Anti-malware Software

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The Google Chrome Cleanup is Enabled by default and each organization should review and determine if they want to use this solutions for malware detection. If another solution is used instead of the built in Chrome option then an organization should configure the setting to Disabled .

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, configure the following setting to meet organizational requirements:
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable Chrome Cleanup on Windows
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Organizational Specific.

NOTE: If Disabled , Chrome Cleanup will no longer be able to scan the system. If users do not have a centrally managed anti-malware solution then leaving this setting Enabled can help protect a system.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable Site Isolation for every site' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls if every website will load into its own process.
Disabled (0): Doesn't turn off site isolation, but it lets users opt out.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled (1)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Chrome will load each website in its own process. So, even if a site bypasses the same-origin policy, the extra security will help stop the site from stealing your data from another website.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable Site Isolation for every site
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

If the policy is enabled, each site will run in its own process which will cause the system to use more memory. You might want to look at the Enable Site Isolation for specified origins policy setting to get the best of both worlds, isolation and limited impact for users, by using Enable Site Isolation for specified origins with a list of the sites you want to isolate.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Force Google SafeSearch' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting ensures that web search results with Google are performed with SafeSearch set to always active. Disabled means SafeSearch in Google Search is not enforced.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled (1)

controls:safeguard.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters
Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Allowing search results to present sites that may have malicious content should be prohibited to help ensure users do not accidentally visit sites that are more prone to malicious content including spyware, adware, and viruses.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via GP, set the following UI path to Enabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Force Google SafeSearch
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Users search results will be filtered and content such as adult text, videos and images will not be shown.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Notify a user that a browser relaunch or device restart is recommended or required' is set to 'Enabled: Show a recurring prompt to the user indication that a relaunch is required' specified

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome can notify users that it must be restarted to apply a pending update once the notification period defined by the recommendation Set the time period for update notifications is passed.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Show a recurring prompt to the user indicating that a relaunch is recommended (1)
Show a recurring prompt to the user indicating that a relaunch is required (2)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Disabled : Google Chrome indicates to the user that a relaunch is needed via subtle changes to its menu.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled with a value of Show a recurring prompt to the user indicating that a relaunch is required (2)

controls:safeguard.title: Perform Automated Application Patch Management
Deploy Automated Software Patch Management Tools

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: The end-user will receive a notification informing them that an update has been applied and that the browser must be restarted in order for the update to be completed. Once updates have been pushed by the organization it is pertinent that the update is applied as soon as possible. Enabling this notification will ensure that users restart their browser in a timely fashion.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: Show a recurring prompt to the user indication that a relaunch is required :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Notify a user that a browser relaunch or device restart is recommended or required
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

A recurring warning will be shown to the user indicating that a browser relaunch will be forced once the notification period passes. The user's session is restored after the relaunch of Google Chrome.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Proxy settings' is set to 'Enabled' and does not contain "ProxyMode": "auto_detect"

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome offers the functionality to configure the proxy settings by automatic discovery using WPAD (Web Proxy Auto-Discovery Protocol). Setting this configures the proxy settings for Chrome and ARC-apps, which ignore all proxy-related options specified from the command line.
Disabled (0): Lets users choose their proxy settings.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled and the value of ProxyMode is not set to auto_detect

controls:safeguard.title: Perform Application Layer Filtering
Deploy Application Layer Filtering Proxy Server

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Attackers may abuse the WPAD auto-config functionality to supply computers with a PAC file that specifies a rogue web proxy under their control.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, make sure the following UI path is set to 'Enabled' and the value of ProxyMode is not set to auto_detect :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Proxy settings
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If the policy is enabled, the proxy configuration will no longer be discovered using WPAD.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Require online OCSP/CRL checks for local trust anchors' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome performs revocation checking for server certificates that successfully validate and are signed by locally-installed CA certificates. If Google Chrome is unable to obtain revocation status information, such certificates will be treated as revoked ('hard-fail').
Disabled : Google Chrome uses existing online revocation-checking settings.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled (1)

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Certificates shall always be validated.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Require online OCSP/CRL checks for local trust anchors
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:

A revocation check will be performed for server certificates that successfully validate and are signed by locally-installed CA certificates. if the OCSP server goes down, then this will hard-fail and prevent browsing to those sites.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Set the time period for update notifications' is set to 'Enabled: 86400000'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome allows to set the time period, in milliseconds, over which users are notified that it must be relaunched to apply a pending update.
If not set, or Disabled , the default period of 604800000 milliseconds (7 days) is used.
The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled with value 86400000 (1 day)

controls:safeguard.title: Perform Automated Application Patch Management
Deploy Automated Software Patch Management Tools

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: This setting is a notification for the end-user informing them that an update has been applied and that the browser must be restarted in order for the update to be completed. Once updates have been pushed by the organization it is pertinent that said update takes affect as soon as possible. Enabling this notification will ensure users restart the browser in a timely fashion.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled: 5265C00 (86400000 in Hexidecimal):
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Polices\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Set the time period for update notifications
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
After this time period, the user will be repeatedly informed of the need for an update until a Browser restart is completed.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section contains recommendations that help improve user privacy. Organizations should review these settings and any potential impacts to ensure they make sense within the environment since they restrict some browser functionality.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Default cookies setting' is set to 'Enabled: Keep cookies for the duration of the session'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: When leaving the setting _RestoreOnStartup _unset results in the use of _DefaultCookiesSetting _for all sites, if it's set. If _DefaultCookiesSetting _is not set, the user's personal setting applies.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0, user's personal setting applies)
Allow all sites to set local data (1)
Do not allow any site to set local data (2)
Keep cookies for the duration of the session (4)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled with a value of Keep cookies for the duration of the session (4)
NOTE: If the RestoreOnStartup setting is set to restore URLs from previous sessions this setting will not be respected and cookies will be stored permanently for those sites.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Permanently stored cookies may be used for malicious intent.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled with Keep cookies for the duration of the session :
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Content Settings\Default cookies setting
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is enabled, cookies will be cleared when the session closes.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Default geolocation setting' is set to 'Enabled: Do not allow any site to track the users' physical location'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Google Chrome supports tracking the users' physical location using GPS, data about nearby Wi-Fi access points or cellular signal sites/towers (even if youre not using them), and your computers IP.

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: Disabled (0, same as 3)
Allow sites to track the users' physical location (1)
Do not allow any site to track the users' physical location (2)
Ask whenever a site wants to track the users' physical location (3)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The recommended state for this setting is: Enabled with a value Do not allow any site to track the users' physical location (3)
